misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (distance formula instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator that maps a single numeric grade (0–100) to a letter grade A–F using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) and outputs the distance between two points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and then use conditional ranges to output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade.
Program computes a square root using the distance formula instead of checking grade ranges.
Program never outputs a letter grade like A, B, C, D, or F.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements, likely confusing this assignment with a distance-between-points exercise or reusing code from a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the program around the specified input (a single grade 0–100) and the required output (letter grade A–F based on the given ranges). Then implement an if–else chain or similar conditional structure to check each range.
related_concepts: Designing input and output based on requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompts, variables, computation, and output) is about point coordinates and distance, with no mention of grades or letter outputs.

evidence.note: All input, processing, and output are for a distance-between-points calculation; there is no grade input or letter grade logic.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program for calculating the distance between two points, completely failing to address the requirements for Q3, which requested a grade calculator program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assigned task was to calculate the distance between two points using coordinate geometry, entirely missing the requirement to implement a grade calculator based on conditional logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional statements (if/else if/else) to output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2
Program calculates mathematical distance using Math.sqrt and Math.pow
No use of conditional statements (if, else if, else)
Output is a floating-point number representing distance, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading or misunderstanding which assignment question the provided code snippet solves.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the prompt for Q3 ('Grade Calculator') and ensure your code addresses all parts of that specific problem: inputting a grade, using if/else logic for ranges, and outputting the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The submitted code solves a common geometric problem (distance formula) and contains zero elements related to the required Grade Calculator problem.

evidence.note: The class name itself indicates the code is solving a different problem than the required Grade Calculator.
The student reads four double inputs (coordinates) instead of a single grade (0-100).

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: The program calculates and outputs geometric distance, confirming the code is for the wrong assignment. There is no conditional logic for grading.

misconceptions.name: Task misalignment - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted a solution to a completely different problem (calculating distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator program requested in Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem rather than a grade classification problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the provided scale. This is fundamentally different from calculating Euclidean distance between two coordinate points.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Program calculates and outputs distance using the distance formula instead of letter grades
No conditional logic for grade ranges (A: 90-100, B: 80-89, C: 70-79, D: 60-69, F: <60)
Output format is completely different from sample run specification
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either misread the assignment, submitted code from a different assignment by mistake, or did not understand the problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the Q3 assignment carefully. The program should: (1) read ONE numeric grade value, (2) use if-else statements to check grade ranges, (3) output the corresponding single letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem with different inputs, logic, and outputs. This is not a minor implementation error but a fundamental misalignment with the assignment.

evidence.note: The entire program implements distance calculation instead of grade classification. It reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) and calculates Euclidean distance, not reading a grade and outputting a letter.
Class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' indicates this is a solution to a different problem entirely.

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program solves an unrelated distance-between-points problem and contains no logic related to grade ranges or letter output.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student misunderstood the assignment completely and wrote a solution for calculating the Euclidean distance between two points instead of a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade and outputs a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The assignment requires reading two coordinate pairs (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and calculating the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment explicitly requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the provided scale.
symptoms: Program reads 4 coordinate values instead of 1 grade value
Program calculates and outputs a distance instead of a letter grade
Program uses Math.sqrt() and distance formula instead of conditional statements for grade ranges
Sample output shows 'Letter grade: B' but student output shows 'The distance of the two points is [number]'
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either did not read the assignment carefully, or submitted code from a different assignment by mistake.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment specification carefully. The program should: (1) Use Scanner to read ONE numeric grade, (2) Use if-else statements to check grade ranges (90-100=A, 80-89=B, etc.), (3) Output a single letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is unambiguous. The student submitted a complete, working program for a different problem (distance calculator). The assignment specifications are clear, and the code has zero overlap with the requirements.

evidence.note: Student reads four coordinate values instead of a single grade value. This demonstrates the student is solving a different problem entirely.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %f%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: Program outputs a distance calculation using Euclidean formula. The assignment requires outputting a letter grade based on numeric grade ranges.
Class is named 'DistanceBetweenPoints' which indicates student is solving a different problem (not grade calculator)
